summary: This is a supplemental declaration filed by Counsel to the Acting U.S. Attorney for the SDNY in support of the BOP's motion for summary judgment in a FOIA case brought by The New York Times. The declaration details the legal basis for withholding certain Bureau of Prisons records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death, citing FOIA Exemption 7(A) to prevent interference with the pending prosecutions of BOP staff (Noel) and inmate Tartaglione.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the FOIA requests and the withheld records. The document discusses records related to his incarceration, psychological notes, and his death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A BOP employee being prosecuted. The declaration argues that releasing records could interfere with the 'Noel prosecution' and the ability to seat a fair jury for that trial.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: An inmate being prosecuted in a separate case (16 Cr. 832). His defense counsel has placed his interactions with Epstein in July 2019 at issue, making certain psychological records and log entries relevant to his potential penalty phase.

persons.name: Kara Christenson
persons.context: Author of a 'Supplemental Declaration' to which an updated index of withheld records is attached.

connections.description: Noel was a BOP employee at the MCC where Epstein was incarcerated. The prosecution of Noel is related to events surrounding Epstein's incarceration and death.

Tartaglione interacted with Epstein in July 2019. His defense counsel has referenced these interactions, making records about Epstein's July 23 suicide attempt potentially relevant to Tartaglione's case.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein had an apparent suicide attempt while incarcerated at the MCC. This event generated psychological notes and log entries that are being withheld from FOIA release.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his cell at the MCC. The document references widespread media coverage and speculation about his death.

events.title: Period Following Epstein's Death
events.description: The day following Epstein's death. BOP records from this date, including SHU rosters and logs, are being withheld.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office is withholding BOP records related to Epstein's incarceration under FOIA Exemption 7(A), arguing release could interfere with the prosecutions of BOP staff (Noel) and inmate Tartaglione.

Withheld records include inmate count documents, staffing rosters, psychological notes on Epstein, and specific BOP logs from August 9-10, 2019, which may be used as trial exhibits or witness testimony.

The declaration states that Tartaglione's defense has placed his interactions with Epstein in July 2019 at issue, making records of Epstein's July 23 suicide attempt potentially relevant to Tartaglione's penalty phase.

The government argues premature release could influence witness testimony, enable witnesses to shape their stories, and impair the ability to seat an impartial jury due to extensive media speculation about Epstein's death.
